Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340424070
You can set the time of death 23 days in advance. The only exception is if you writes that the person dies of a long lasting disease and no other details, they will die in an appropriate time for the disease. e.g. write "cancer" as the cause of death and they could live longer than 23 days, but you can't manipulate them if you do it like this.
You also can't use the death note to set a later time of death than their original lifespan, however killing someone else who would have decreased another person's lifespan will increase their lifespan, but if a death god does that on purpose they die.

Here's a study in zinc and the cold:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7356429/

They perform quite differently, depending on the form. Too much zinc also can cause copper deficiency.

I also keep hearing that Vitamin D3 should go with Vitamin K, especially when dosed high.

Biovailability in different forms in general is a problem. Just because it says "X" on the supplement doesn't mean your body will actually take it up and then it also depends on your weight and body fat. It's best to do get some bloodwork done.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340318131
>the droplets carrying influenza and COVID virus particles are of identical size and that masks would either stop both or neither
Not completely true:

a. They're of identical size distribution, not size

b. In theory, it'd be possible for a mask that filters out just the larger droplets to filter out enough that there's no longer an infectious quantity of influenza left, but not enough to reduce covid below the infectiou quantity, as covid both produces a higher virus concentration and needs less viruses to infect you.
That's unlikely given he wide spread of masks being used, but theoretically possible.

c. influenza spreads only through breathing the virus. covid also spreads through the eyes. So with masks that actually do protect you (in other words, ffp3 or n95 with valve, not random rags of cloth or dust masks that'll slide of your face the moment you exhale), they protect completely against influenza, but incompletely against covid.

There's enough bullshit being spread by politicians and "experts" on tv. You don't need to add to that.

Far left commie SJW shithole. With less people going to college due to the fact that it isn't needed, more trades jobs needed, there will naturally be less latte liberals further indoctrinated by this shithole

Will die due to the fact that their technology only took off because you needed to pay to text

>LinkedIn
Not actively used, something you have to showcase your resume at a high level to a prospect HR for a new job, but not something people check in on daily or keep scrolling. It has a low ceiling is what I'm saying

>Skype
Facetime, Teams, Zoom, and Google Hangouts have more or less eliminated the need

>Tinder/Bumble

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340330167
Not necessarily. Adrenaline is a hell of a drug. It can allow you to ignore your emotive pain response, but you can't ignore the physiological reality of vital processes shutting down. Adrenaline can keep you alert, functioning, standing on your feet, but if you're rapidly losing blood you will just collapse at some point. It is also the case that a lot of people who get shot and fall down will get up and walk around after a minute. Its somewhat common for EMS to have to search for a shooting victim because they got up and left the scene after being seemingly unconscious.

The mental state of a person at the time you start treating them has no bearing on their likelihood to survive or how severe their wounds actually are.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340326055
I'm not going to comment on the social or political aspects, but just give you a quick snapshot of their demographics and future.

-

Ukraine currently loses around 350k a year people due to natural population decline, and 150k due to immigration, so that's over 500k a year. There are less children being born every year since 2012 and the population loss is also accelerating. They already have the lowest total fertility rate in Europe, and by the looks of things, are heading towards the lowest in the world. 

2012 520,705 -142,434 1,53
2013 503,657 -158,711 1,51
2014 465,882 -166,414 1,50
2015 411,781 -183,015 1,51
2016 397,037 -186,594 1,47
2017 363,987 -210,136 1,37
2018 335,874 -251,791 1,30
2019 308,817 -272,297 1,23
2020 293,457 -323,378 ~1,1-1,15

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Ukraine

A year ago the population was 37 million, according to their government estimates. 

https://www.pravda.com.ua/rus/news/2020/01/23/7238191/

The processes I described above will continue accelerating and by 2040, 2/3 of 22 million remaining population will be retirees. By 2050, it will be 9/10, with the total population being around 15 million. Over the next 30 years, about 10 million of them will immigrate to Russia to avoid the economic collapse caused by demographics, the first signs of which already being voiced by their finance minister. He says people under 40 shouldn't count on receiving any pensions due to there being less working age people every year and more retirees. Use google translate if you're interested. 

https://www.epravda.com.ua/rus/news/2021/08/26/677219/

The 15 million remaining by 2050 will have to be provided for by tens of billions in humanitarian aid, otherwise they will die of hunger without electricity, clean water, medical aid, police and sewage.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
No one topic has more misunderstanding and shilling than this one.

Yes, masks work. Even simple surgical masks drastically reduce influenza infection rate among dentists and doctors working with sick patients. Given the coronavirus family will also operate by droplet transmission, they will be fine against that too.

Frequently even MDs fuck up that the virus is much smaller than the pore size of the mask, therefore masks are useless. These people forget that youre unlikely to inhale a floating viral particle, but a droplet as a result of sneezing or coughing. Masks will stop that.

However: wearing a wet cloth around your face for hours a day is a very bad idea and probably does increase pneumonia (aspiration pneumonia?) incidence. Masks are to be disposable and changed between exposures, none of which we saw with mask mandates. Moreover once the masks become wet (from extended use) you start to inhale whats been caught.

So tl;dr: Yes, masks work. But no, not how they were mandated for every swinging dick to wear for hours a day.

t. pgy1 IM who put more hours into preparing this shit at the start of this fiasco than I can count

Title: Mass extinction event on Earth?
Content:
https://www.vice.com/en/article/bvzqg5/a-warning-sign-of-a-mass-extinction-event-is-on-the-rise-scientists-say

Harmful algal and bacterial blooms on the shores might be early indications of a mass extinction event. 

Remember dinosaurs? They died 65 million years ago in a mass extinction. Something similar may be going on now.

251 million years ago, the end-Permian event (EPE), popularly known as the "Great Dying," 

>wiped out nearly 90 percent of species on Earth, 

making it the most severe loss of life in our planet's history. 

However EPE gave rise to the dinosaurs because a small rat like tree dwelling lizard was the ancestor of dinosaurs and it survived.

Ominous parallels of that upheaval are now showing up on Earth, according to a team led by Chris Mays, a postdoctoral researcher and palaeobotanist at the Swedish Museum of Natural History in Stockholm. 

>The researchers found that toxic algal and bacterial blooms during the Great Dying are similar to a recent microbial proliferation in modern lakes and rivers

- a trend that has been linked to human activities such as greenhouse gas emissions (especially carbon dioxide), deforestation, and soil loss.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
The repeated correlation of these blooms with mass extinction events is "a disconcerting signal for future environmental change," report the researchers in a study published on Friday in the journal Nature Communications. Indeed, there's a lot of evidence to suggest we are currently in the midst of yet another mass extinction event, caused by humans. 

Not only do microbial blooms transform freshwater habitats into "dead zones" that can both choke out other species, thereby increasing the severity of extinction events, they can also delay the recovery of ecosystems by millions of years, the team noted. Mays and his colleagues reached this troubling conclusion by analyzing fossil records near Sydney, Australia, that were laid down before, during, and after the end-Permian extinction.

Though the exact mechanisms behind the Great Dying are a matter of debate, it was driven in part by an intense bout of volcanic eruptions that sparked a dramatic uptick in global temperatures and greenhouse gases emissions. Wildfires, droughts, and other disruptions swept across the woodlands, causing a collapse of plant life and widespread deforestation. 

The sudden loss of forests, which act as a sink for carbon, created a noticeable "coal gap" during the end-Permian that exposes this long-term interruption in carbon sequestration. Nutrients and soils that had once been metabolized by these botanical ecosystems instead seeped into nearby freshwater habitats, bolstering microbial blooms that were already thriving as a result of higher temperature and atmospheric carbon.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340338969
No, the culture of the US is a hybrid of that of the British Empire and the European colonisers of the New World.
As a result you can expect that the culture of whites is going to have elements of both those cultures.
The culture of the British Empire, with which most whites (or those with European origins who settled in the US) had more or less direct contact, includes elements such as formal dining, table manners and formal etiquette, with which most American culture still bears a striking resemblance.
On a day-to-day basis many of these elements are absent.
For example, we don't have dinner jackets or ties.
And we eat most meals (and socialise) in casual clothes or even casual work clothes.
This is a more casual culture than the British (which was heavily influenced by the French).
On top of that, many of the traditional American social conventions are not well-known in the UK. For example, Americans often use the word "please" more or less in place of "you're welcome" when it is appropriate.
This is true even for those born in the US.
For example, the phrase "you're welcome" can come across to someone unfamiliar with American culture as being sarcastic or even insulting when used this way.

Content:
>>340334566
>I can't make women laugh or get them to show attraction to me
You can't "make" anyone do anything. You can only put yourself out there and let people react how they're going to. Really, this attempt to elicit a certain reaction is built on a fallacious assumption that you have more agency than you actually do. This fallacy leads to you believing that it's some kind of failing on your part. In reality, it's this dynamic as it exists in and of itself which precludes your success. People in general can sniff out desperation, and they will intuit that you believe there is some kind of casual chain between your actions and your expected outcomes. If you detach from this entire dynamic, everything falls into place eventually.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340341926
>It may be "transactional" but that's the right kind of transaction to have in the sexual marketplace
I don't believe humans can be reduced in this way – at least not healthily. I don't believe any system based explicitly on humans being commodities is one which has much of a future. I believe that much of the unrest in the developed world is abstracted from the dehumanizing effects of postmodern, late capitalism. More than anything else, I reject your assumption that this market-based philosophy is one which has any particular merit to it. To the contrary, I believe that as more and more young men lash out against this dynamic, which shapes their lives but never fully comes into focus, we will see the real effects of the dehumanization. We'll see the violence and we'll just pass them off as "faulty products" on the marketplace while they gun people down and run them over with trucks. A human being is not a commodity, and interactions between us are not transactions. Nature is transactional, but we have risen above nature's zero sum game by rising above. We became humans to conquer our world, and now we're in the process of returning ourselves to its ecosystem.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
Nicotine Inhibits Aromatase (The Enzyme Which Converts Testosterone to Estrogen)

>Nicotine Blocks Brain Estrogen Synthase (Aromatase): In Vivo Positron Emission Tomography Studies in Female Baboons "The size of the effect (more than 50% of the maximal inhibition obtained with a blocking dose of vorozole) suggests that nicotine is capable of inhibiting the activity of aromatase in the primate brain."

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2904480/


JCI - Nicotine, cotinine, and anabasine inhibit aromatase in human trophoblast in vitro.

>"In choriocarcinoma cell cultures, nicotine, cotinine (a major metabolite of nicotine), and anabasine (a minor component of cigarette tobacco) all inhibited androstenedione conversion to estrogen in a dose-dependent fashion. Removal of nicotine, cotinine, and anabasine from the culture medium resulted in the complete reversal of the inhibition of aromatase."

https://www.jci.org/articles/view/112494


Potential Contribution of Aromatase Inhibition to the Effects of Nicotine and Related Compounds on the Brain

>"Thus, we have shown that nicotine doses producing plasma levels comparable with those found in smokers are capable of a significant but partial (∼50%) inhibition of aromatase."

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3490106/

In shamanic tradition, tabaco is known as a teacher plant. It's one of the main ones shamans use. Why?

Well, people in indigenous communities are usually only inducted into a shamanic practice if they "see spirits." Here in our enlightened clown world, when people see spirits, we call them schizophrenic and force them to take nerve toxins every day. Interestingly, not only neuroleptics are indicated for schizophrenia. Tobacco is indicated for schizophrenia! Smoking gives them relief from the symptoms which cause them distress. It's kind of the same thing with shamans. Smoking helps them achieve a sort of balance between mundane reality and the things they perceive which others do not. It has a purgative, grounding effect.

I learned a very interesting approach to smoking tobacco from one of these dudes. You can use smoking as a prayer ritual. The idea is to imbue smoke in your lungs with your prayer, then exhale it unto the ears of the Great Spirit. It's a practice which has worked for me. Instead of sucking down a cigarette, I can sit down, connect, meditate, and really enjoy it.

To the smokers ITT, switch to Senecas. They are an additive free, Indian owned brand based out of Canada, and they're less than half the price of American Spirits.

The Guard

Plot

Sergeant Gerry Boyle is an officer of the Garda Sochna in Connemara in the west of Ireland. He is crass and confrontational, regularly indulging in drugs and alcohol even while on duty. He is also shown to have a softer side, showing concern for his ailing mother, Eileen.

Boyle and his new subordinate, Aidan McBride, investigate a murder, with evidence apparently pointing to an occult serial killer. Shortly after, Boyle attends a briefing by FBI agent Wendell Everett, sent to liaise with the Garda in hunting down four Irish drug traffickers, led by Francis Sheehy-Skeffington, who is believed to be awaiting a delivery of cocaine. Boyle recognises one of the men in Everett's presentation as the victim of the murder he and McBride had been investigating. McBride pulls over a car driven by Sheehy and his lieutenants Clive Cornell and Liam O'Leary and is shot dead. McBride's wife, Gabriela, reports McBride's disappearance to Boyle, who promises to look into it.

Calvary 


Plot

In a dark Catholic confessional, an unseen man tells Father James he was horribly sexually abused as a child by a priest, promising to kill James at the beach the next Sunday (James being a good man whose death will hurt the church more than would the death of an abusive priest). James has a week to arrange his affairs. His bishop leaves it to James to decide whether to notify the police.

James' daughter Fiona has attempted suicide after feeling abandoned following her mother's death and her father's entry into the priesthood. Their rapprochement is a principal theme of the film.

Local butcher Jack Brennan has hit his unfaithful wife, Veronica, and James confronts him. Jack denies it, blaming Veronica's African lover, Simon. James goes about his pastoral duties, and obtains a revolver for an elderly American writer who is contemplating suicide to thwart senile decay.

Content:
Just take steroids. 

There's no possible way in which you will increase your T levels significantly under the conditions of modernity. You are surrounded by pollutants, you breathe them, ingest them, or even listen to them (noise pollution is incredibly stressful). 
The very social fabric in which you live and its culture are pollutants, they drain you of your life force, they fill your mind and psyche with silly and stressful images and ideas and this drops your T. You are also not allowed to express yourself and as yourself freely so you are tense and walking on egg shells all day, this drops your T.

If you have 200 ng/dl of T and you double it, which is an astounding feat in itself, you will still be low T.

But there's no way you can recover what was once considered "normal" T levels on the 900 ng/dl, just by taking zinc (which could deplete your copper levels long-term) and doing weightlifting, if you are still an everyday victim of modernity. You are wasting money.

8% increase in T by weightlifting as OP image states is an absolute insignificance. I wage you would increase your T much more just by going to live in the countryside.

I'm just being realistic. You people need to realize the extreme point in which this world has damaged you, where you can't even produce hormones normally. 
Don't even need to get supraphysiological levels, just on the trt ranges.

So somehow Noah got 2 of each animal on the ark. He got all the food to feed them. Then the entire earth flooded (literally zero evidence that ever happened). These animals would then in-breed generation after generation to create the innumerable species we know today.

There's also the question of how Noah got animals from all the continents onto his ark, and how those animals spread themselves to the various continents afterwards. For example, Eucalyptus is native to Australia, and is the only food for koalas. Somehow after the flood, these koalas crossed all of Asia, and swam to Australia, without any eucalyptus leaves to eat. And when they got to australia, all the eucalyptus would be dead, with the land salted and barren from the flood.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340331050
>America gives Taliban the third largest military overnight.
Small arms are just small arms. It's poor optics to see the Taliban walking around with M4's and driving around in MRAPs, but these things are complete military nonissues. What else did we even leave behind? Nothing anyone can even use. Some Hummers with old-ass GDLS terminals? Those things are a fucking joke. I deployed to Southern Afghanistan in 09 and after we realized that the fancy ass new age connectivity systems barely even worked, we never turned them on again. 

Anything the Taliban wants to operate themselves rather than just learn from? Good fucking luck. As someone who's spent hours of his life working on these overpriced pieces of shit, again, good fucking luck. They might be able to keep a Hummer running, but something like an MRAP or an Abrams is just way beyond anyone in Afghanistan. Even if they COULD work on this equipment, they rely on parts they can't get. GD isn't exactly selling it on the open market, and good luck fabricating them. 

Some other retards have made bitch faces about radios left behind. These people have no clue what they're talking about. They've never had to watch their platoon's RTO spend five hours a week applying the new encryption codes to the radios. Radio itself is not a new technology – it's our encryption which is modern. Having physical possession of a number of radios, even fully functional ones, does not mean they'll be able to crack our encryption, which changes on a ridiculously frequent basis. 

The whole thing is a nothingburger. What the Taliban can actually use, they can't project. I doubt they could get it twenty miles outside their borders. """"Third largest military"""". My fucking ass.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340313966
>does the 22lr round even pass the fbi/cia caliber test?
That's not a minimum standard of handgun effectiveness, it's an arbitrary standard, and not an especially well chosen or relevant one.

For civilian self-defense, terminal effect rarely matters. If you present something that looks like a firearm, it will scare off 90+% of criminals. If it makes a flash and loud bang, it will scare off 99+%. If it hits them and makes them bleed, 99.9+% will desperately flee or surrender and beg for help (if they're still able). The other uncertainties are far larger than whether your bullet has enough stopping power.

Against someone who feels their only option is to fight (as cops often face) or willing to die to kill you (as soldiers often face), terminal effect matters a lot more, yet the only reliable fast stop with a conventional pistol (i.e. not something rifle-powered like a .50 AE Desert Eagle) comes from shooting the brain, which .22 LR can also do. While much fuss is made over differences in stopping power between pistol calibers, the real advantages you're gaining from going up to a conventional round like 9mm are longer effective range and being able to penetrate light barriers and light armor (such as flak jackets and helmets).

It's easy to armor against .22LR, you could make a full body suit that would make you totally immune to .22 LR fire, or you can wear very comfortable .22 LR stopping armor under your clothes. That's why nobody's going to arm an organized force with something as weak as .22 LR when enemies might anticipate fighting against them and prepare specifically against the .22 LR threat. In the past, it was fairly common for police to be armed with .25 and .32 caliber pistols with similar power to .22 LR (and more reliable centerfire primers), but they pretty much all moved up to .38 (9mm) or larger many decades ago.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340315531
Not in .22 LR, against human targets, except possibly if you can only get round-nose and you know you're firing out of rifle-length barrel at close range. You can buy hollow points (designed to expand) and segmented (designed to split apart) .22 LR ammo off the shelf.

Segmented is good for varmints, greatly reducing penetration depth (which you don't need as much of in a small animal), in exchange for cutting multiple wound tracks, making a badly-placed shot more likely to be fatal anyway. Hollow point is designed for controlled expansion, which does enhance the terminal effect, provided the bullet is going fast enough for the impact to cause the expansion to happen, and the bullet can still penetrate deeply enough after expanding.

Out of a pistol, .22 hollow point won't expand (because it's going slower and so doesn't slap the target as fiercely), and you wouldn't want it to. You're struggling to get enough penetration depth. A half-assed modification of a bullet to try and make it expand more like cutting a cross on the tip is probably going to make it unstable in flight, and might screw up its ability to penetrate sufficiently.

Usually a "flower petal" bullet is jacketed, with the copper jacket holding the bullet together as the petals fold out. Lead is a much weaker metal, and .22 LR bullets don't have copper jackets (though they sometimes have a very thin "copper wash"), so trying to recreate the same effect probably makes bullets that break apart into smaller pieces that don't get very far into the target.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340328988
Choosing a weapon isn't about optimizing heavily for performance, it's mostly about practicality: what's available, reliable, and good enough for your intended application.

You need some very good reasons to choose (for fighting purposes) an autoloading pistol that's not 9mm, a revolver that's not .357 Magnum (loaded with either .357 Magnum or .38 Special), a shotgun that's not 12 gauge, a fast-shooting semiauto rifle that's not 5.56, or a bolt-action (or otherwise highly accurate and intended for long-range use) rifle that's not .308. These are standard, they wouldn't have become standard if they weren't basically good choices, and going with the standard makes life easier in a thousand ways.

In the chaos of battle, small differences in bullet performance rarely prove critical, while supply chain problems often cause disaster.

>>340333408
A world-record grizzly was once taken with .22 Long (a cartridge weaker than .22 LR) fired from a single-shot rifle into its head (specifically at a weak point where the skull is thin). It's true that a lot of performance is lost when the barrel is shortened, but there are places you can shoot a grizzly with a .22 pistol and kill it fast.

(I wouldn't want to try when it's trying to eat me, though.)

Well, in a sense you're correct. USA business interests do have a lot more leverage here than the UK ones. However, you are making the mistake of assuming trade deals orchestrated by the USA are done for the benefit of USA citizens, which is patently false.
> the UK has no leverage

Also, they still have the appearance of a global power even if that practical reality has vanished, it has been good PR for the USA to seem to have a serious & powerful ally in all of our middle east adventures for example. We certainly don't want the UK to cozy up to China, that could create a LOT of problems for us in the long term. The UK could give them tons of support in all of the areas they are lacking. That would be an extreme change of course though, probably not palatable to the people or even the government.
The most likely outcome of all of this is a shitty trade deal between the US and UK that benefits only the corporate interests and is slanted towards the US interests more-so. Basically, a nothingburger.

I don't know what you're talking about, but we're still a great power both on paper and in practice. We're a financial heavyweight and the EU tried every trick in the book to keep us in because they knew that without our money, they're fucked. British money practically kept the Euro alive as British taxpayers bailed out a currency we don't even use.
Militarily, our reputation right now is better than America's as we didn't just embarrass and humiliate ourselves in Afghanistan. Pretty much all the negative press was on America, meanwhile we're increasing our commitments in the Indo-Pacific.
As for what we can offer, it's not as if we don't have any resources anymore. Yes, our industries were outsourced, but we sti have vast deposits of shale, coal, and North Sea oil. Furthermore, if we transition to nuclear power for domestic energy use, not only can we export more of our raw materials, but we can use more in our automotive industry, as British cars are coveted around the world (Rolls Royce, Bentley, Lotus, Aston Martin, to name but a few). Yes, we don't have the industrial potential of countries like Canada or Australia because we're a tiny, incredibly densely populated country, but it's not as if there's nothing here.

Name: Anonymous

>>340319172
>but we're still a great power both on paper and in practice
Great power sure, but not global and not in the same tier as the USA. I already pointed out your financial sector is one of your true assets, so no argument from me there. I'm not saying the UK is powerless.
> EU tried every trick in the book to keep us in because they knew that without our money, they're fucked.
They're fucked regardless, yes they would have preferred you in and it would give them more wiggle room, but the demographic collapse is baked in now and there is no stopping that. 
>military reputation better
Another point I explicitly pointed out, but again reputation and practical reality are two different things. The US wants UK troops for propaganda, not for manpower or tech. As President Johnson's National Security Advisor said back during Vietnam "a British Brigade in Vietnam would be worth a billion dollars". The same is basically true today. 
>As for what we can offer, it's not as if we don't have any resources anymore.
Also true, but we already basically have our fill locally and with Canada & Mexico, so you're selling into a saturated market which dilutes the potency of that as a bargaining chip. 
>Yes, we don't have the industrial potential of countries like Canada or Australia because we're a tiny, incredibly densely populated country, but it's not as if there's nothing here.
I completely agree here mate. All I was saying is that the UK is worth more on paper than in reality and that the US has "more" leverage in these negotiations, not all of it. The UK obviously still has plenty to offer, and your deal will almost certainly be superior to any "losses" from the EU fallout, but the US is going to set most of the terms here if allowing one of its competitors into its trade deals.

>Great power sure, but not global and not in the same tier as the USA
We are global, but not on the same tier as the US. As I pointed out, we're stepping up our military commitments in the Indo-Pacific.
>They're fucked regardless, yes they would have preferred you in and it would give them more wiggle room, but the demographic collapse is baked in now and there is no stopping that.
It's now more blatantly France and Germany telling everyone else what to do, and we're not there to keep them in check. The Poles and Hungarians will ignore them and the Italians will start getting angry. A lot more intra-national tension in the EU, especially now our money is gone and the French and Germans want other countries to plug the gap.
>reputation and practical reality are two different things.
Correct, and the world has just seen the Americans lose another war after twenty years and God knows how much money. The USA's allies are shoring up other alliances because many consider the US military to be no longer dependable. Besides, they also have a reputation of getting other countries like the UK to fight its wars, but the UK isn't seen as America's lap dog anymore, which is good for us.
>we already basically have our fill locally and with Canada & Mexico
That is a good point. There's still a huge debate about shale and fracking here which stonewalls any progress there. I suppose the question is "can you get natural resources from Mexico as reliably as you can from the UK?", but then there's the matter of us not sharing a border with you. I refer you to my earlier point about cars. Highly coveted British brands most definitely have what the Canadians and Mexicans don't. Besides, we also have shipbuilding still, and a good reputation for that. Cars aren't everything, but this is a good example.

Name: Anonymous
Content: How can Finland become an industrial powerhouse?

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340341044
Finland is well positioned at this stage of economic growth to continue to take advantage of its natural abundance and its ability to produce and export goods that are not only essential to Europe, but are also a commodity on the world market. The country is blessed with raw material resources like forestry and iron, as well as an industrial potential that continues to grow. These factors coupled with a stable political system and strong social cohesion have made Finland a good place for investors to look at and for foreign companies to move into as a base from which to expand their businesses further afield.

The country’s position is also helped by high levels of education and a strong cultural tradition. According to the International Labour Organization, more than a third of the Finnish population are engaged in tertiary education in some form or another – making Finland by far the most highly educated nation among the OECD. In 2015, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development named Finland the best country in the world for its education system.

At its core wages are a supply and demand problem. If you have more workers than jobs, the workers compete against each other for positions which drives wages down. Content:
So there is some kind of anxiety about people not being back in the office. They're trying to frame it as "The great wait".

Name: Anonymous
Content:
I just don't think the quality of live improvement of working from home is ever going to be out-compensated by any kind of pay increases, especially when just having the workers return tot he office objectively costs the company more money. 

Any archaic companies who were resistant to WFH have had their hands forced, had to develop a new process to accommodate it because of covid, something they wouldn't have otherwise ever have invested time and effort into.

Now that they have implemented it, I can't imagine how they would be looking at a balance sheet, seeing huge savings, and not want to keep it. Or maximize it. 

It's exposing the do-nothing workers and how much dead weight they've been paying for with nothing to show.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340328783
 You make a lot of assumptions that are not accurate.

 1. Not all businesses need their people to work in the office. There are more reasons than that.

 2. Most people don't work from home.

 3. It's a win/win for employees and customers if employees are at home. But what about customers who have no internet and can't check their emails or contact the business? It sucks for them. Businesses make money when people buy. If you're not doing anything, you'll lose customers.

 And you've been thinking about this all wrong:

 1. If everybody is working remotely, how many sales do you think that will lead to?

 2. Most places have employees that do most of the sales, if you're an employer, what if your sales employees have no internet/can't access business apps they use to make appointments?

 3. If it's a small business, how can you justify hiring salespeople without internet access?

 4. If you have a business model that requires an office where salespeople actually meet with customers and show them your products, how are you going to be able to make sales if your employees are not present?

 5. There will be a huge number of salespeople, and some people may do better than others selling from an office. How are you going to be able to evaluate a salesperson who isn't selling to real customers?

 6. There is no reason to be making these assumptions about remote working because it's not going to become a thing. Why would it?

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340328783
"Working from home" is the third knock out blow to western jobs in the last 50 years. The first was after the oil crisis of 1973. Companies started moving jobs away from the west. The second was the huge influx of immigrants particularly starting in the 1990s. His pushed down wages further. The third is "Work from Home". The whole point of it is to increase competition by you having to compete not just with locals but people from all over the world. If your company can connect with you 30 miles away via the internet, they can also connect with someone 1,000 miles away in a different continent. This means the internationalization of what were once local jobs via the digital abolition of distance
No only that, read Covid-19 : The Great Reset. It explains how working from home saves companies money because the employee now provides the office, rather than the company. Not only that, employees will become short term contractors who can be terminated easily and won't be provided with pensions or other employee benefits. While the short term benefits are pleasant, the long term effects are likely to be devastating

Kefir made at home with kefir grains and the best quality supermarket milk is fine. I just get Jersey cow milk (more natural) ferment it for 24 hours in a warm place, remove the grains, whisk it with a fork to a good consistency and put it in the fridge to chill. I used to use raw milk but it's pretty expensive because of the shipping costs. The kefir grains will add a lot of life back into the milk. I just recommend using a natural cow breed or goat/sheep milk.

Content:
Not a cop or military but just always had a way with strategy around battle type situations and you can see the organisation is poor even to the point when they are on a block with the cops blocking from front the protestors don't watch their rear and don't watch their flanks. All they need is 15 people to secure each flank and rear to push attackers back and allow for escape down side streets etc. Add to this few scout spotters on bikes in front and circling, few radio comms and few guys with loud speakers communicating to the crowd. Some other things I noticed are the infiltrators. They will do things like guide them into traps, split them off or just hide while taking high Def photos for Intel. These guys are usually marked, usually from the rear with red tape or something, it'll be obvious, they stand out because they try too hard to blend in. The decentralised approach works well sometimes but not once facing real

Reminder: thermite can be used to destroy even the most heavily armored Minecraft vehicles. The in-game recipe is powdered aluminum, powdered rust, mixed in a plant pot (crafting recipe for plant pot is on Minecraft wiki), then using a sparkler to ignite. >>340331155
you don't even need powdered aluminium
>get alfoil or whatever brand kitchen foil
>stiff wire brush
>but of rusty iron
>mixing bowl, paintbrush and oven
>bench clamp/vise
the shiny side of the foil is smooth, the dull side has imperfections. You want the dull side
brush rust powder off iron and put it in a bowl
mix with water until you have a thin paste
paint on the dull side of the foil
dry in oven so that all the water evaporates
fold the foil until you cant any more, then use the vise to keep folding
you'll end up with a wad of flakey, rusty aluminium

Like I said, I'm talking about rising junk food prices by at least double, maybe more. You like lots of sugar and/or calories in your processed food? Good, but pay up thrice as much from now on.
Then use the money to fund government-subsidized dietitians, gyms, etc. We already do this in Mexico, though that tax money goes straight to public hospitals. They're currently testing the junk food tax in Mexico, and if it works out, they're rolling similar programs in the first world. I can already tell it works. I now only drink mineral water instead of sugary soft drinks, because their prices are ridiculously high. Other people have cut down on junk food and sugary drinks as well.
Also, I think making junk food packaging ugly and unappealing would work, like they've done for cigarettes.

Title: Brit/pol/
Content:
Joe Biden plays down chances of UK-US trade deal
>Joe Biden has played down the chances of a post-Brexit free trade deal between the US and UK, as he held talks with Boris Johnson at the White House. The US president said he would discuss the issue "a little bit" with the UK prime minister, adding: "We're going to have to work that through." Downing Street said a direct deal with the US remained the "priority". But UK ministers are pondering joining an existing North American trade pact instead, the BBC understands. Mr Biden and Mr Johnson also discussed Northern Ireland, climate change and Afghanistan during the 90-minute meeting. The UK is keen to strike free trade deals around the world in the wake of leaving the European Union's single market - including with the US, with which annual trade was worth an estimated $273bn (£200bn) in 2019. A deal would encourage more business between the two countries by making it cheaper, usually by reducing or eliminating taxes called tariffs.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
CF Industries: CO2 production deal agreed amid food shortage fears
>The government has struck a deal with a US company to restart production of carbon dioxide (CO2) at plants in the UK after warnings of food shortages. CF Industries stopped work at two of its fertiliser factories, which supplies most of the CO2 used in food production, due to soaring gas prices. CO2 is widely used in the food industry in brewing and in packaging for meat and salads to prolong shelf life. It is not clear yet what incentives the government have offered the firm. The business secretary previously ruled out nationalising the company, although providing financial support is still seen as an unusual move. It could take as long as three days for the factories to start producing CO2 again at its plants in Cheshire and Stockton-on-Tees. The deal comes after one food industry group warned that consumers could start noticing gaps on supermarket shelves within days if there was no intervention in its supply. Carbon dioxide, produced at the two plants as a by-product, is used when slaughtering pigs and chickens to stun them. It is also used in beer and fizzy drinks, as well as in the vacuum-packing process.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
Taliban ask to speak at UN General Assembly in New York
>The Taliban have asked to address world leaders at the United Nations General Assembly this week in New York City. A UN committee will rule on the request but it is unlikely to happen during the current session of the body. The Taliban also nominated their Doha-based spokesperson, Suhail Shaheen, as Afghanistan's UN ambassador. The group, which seized control of Afghanistan last month, said the envoy for the ousted government no longer represented the country. The request to participate in the high-level debate is being considered by a credentials committee, whose nine members include the US, China and Russia, according to a UN spokesperson. But they are unlikely to meet before the end of the General Assembly session next Monday. Until then, under UN rules, Ghulam Isaczai will remain Afghanistan's ambassador to the global body. He is expected to make a speech on the final day. However the Taliban said his mission "no longer represents Afghanistan". No government has formally recognised the Taliban as Afghanistan's new government and for the UN to agree to its nominee for ambassador would be an important step towards international acceptance. The Taliban also said that several countries no longer recognised former President Ashraf Ghani as leader.

Got distracted earlier from telling my story. I went out about 6 30 am to go to tesco, didn't know many people went to work that early but I dodged 3 or 4 cars before I even got out of my estate, hundreds of cars already were rushing along the big road at the edge of town. Got too much stuff to carry so I may have looked a bit silly trying to get it back to my house, bread rolls balancing on my bike and all that, went past a chinese woman and some young women waiting for the bus, a chub ylooking ginger one and one that looked white but not quite, something wasn't quite right, a bit like Kim Kardashian but more arab or jewish sort of genes, I realize that i'm surrounded by people who have a totally different culture to me, they are not english countryside people, and they probably think I look funny, I feel like the one out of place not them even though I have lived here all my life, and of course I see many different BAMES and its not even 8 am yet. 
So its like, I can't even go out at 6 in the morning and live a peaceful and laid back sort of european lifestyle, i'm watched by hundreds of cars too. I think its really a shame what 'jew build' houses and major roads are doing to our little towns and villages.

What I found was that the J&J-Janssen was the most dangerous, with the most deaths and the second higest number ofadverse effects afterModerna. Moderna had the most adverse effects overall but the lowest death rate overall.
I made a league table:

MOST DEATHS:
(1) J&J-Janssen
(2) AstraZeneca
(3) Pfizer 
(4) Moderna

MOST ADVERSE EFFECTS OVERALL - INJURIES AND DEATHS:
(1) Moderna
(2) J&J - Janssen
(3) AstraZeneca
(4) Pfizer

From memory, the official overall adverse effects from each vaccine is approximately
Moderna: 1 reported case of adverse effects per 160 injections
J&J-Janssen: 1 reported case of adverse effects per 162 injections
AstraZeneca: 1 case of adverse effects per 226 injections
Pfizer: 1 case of adverse effects per 360 injections
Summary: J&J has the most deaths, and Moderna has the least, but the most adverse effects in total. J&J is most likely to kill you, and Moderna is most likely to injure you.

>imagine a volcano rupturing a fissure under water, spilling in billions of gallons of water into a cauldron with 3000 degree magma. The pressure will be so insane, it will likely lift the whole side of the mountain 200 feet in the air when the explosion happens.

You dont understand the most basics of physics. What the redneck did was to heat water in a pressure vessel to way over 100 C boiling point which is possible because as the pressure on liquid water rises, the boiling point increases, so the water inside was waaaaaaay over the boiling point at athmospheric pressure but kept in liquid form due to the pressure inside the water heater. When his water heater ruptured due to him plugging the safety vent, all the water inside the water heater turned to steam immediately, greatly increasing the volume of gas inside the bathroom, causing this explosion. The redneck was a double up idiot because him keeping the water heater at this high temperature also maximized his energy losses. 

What would happen in a volcano is that an underground reservoir of water is superheated, the enormous pressure makes the volcano bulge outwards, this causes a crack or a landslide, this relieves the pressure on the underground heated reservoir, which instantly turns into steam, booom!. These blasts can be pretty huge, the one at krakatoa was estimated to be at around 800 megatons. 

Your scenario is a gradual process that would not lead to an explosion.

Name: Anonymous
Content:
>>340348708
>Helium Isotopic Ratio is medium/high (the fuck is this?)
so tl;dr they're watching for Helium-3, a helium isotope created by supernovas and generally only found deep underground on earth where it hasn't been able to escape into space yet.
so, in short, the more He3 magma is putting out, the deeper the likely origin of the magma is.
this can be used to figure out whether volcanic activity is surface fuckery or deep crust/upper mantle movement.
this is about the extent of my knowledge as a physics fag, maybe a volcano/geology fag can elaborate further.

The area highlighted in the pink area (1) has already been splitting off in a previous slide it split and sank but didnt detach and end up in the ocean (2) has a massive amount of magma pushing up below it, causing a slip effect by adding a liquid substrate below the rock layers, aiding in this section of rock to potentially slip off into the ocean (3) the massive amount of earthquakes likely broke tons of fissures in the rock layers, further unsettling the ground.

Azazel, in Jewish legends, a demon or evil spirit to whom, in the ancient rite of Yom Kippur (Day of Atonement), a scapegoat was sent bearing the sins of the Jewish people. Two male goats were chosen for the ritual, one designated by lots “for the Lord,” the other “for Azazel” (Leviticus 16:8). The ritual was carried out by the high priest in the Second Temple and is described in the Mishna. After the high priest symbolically transferred all the sins of the Jewish people to the scapegoat, the goat destined “for Azazel” was driven into the wilderness and cast over a precipice to its death. Azazel was the personification of uncleanness and in later rabbinic writings was sometimes described as a fallen angel.

>Why EU support for France over Aukus has been muted

>Beyond the commercial loss of a contract worth AUD90bn to France’s critical defence industry, the pact also raises questions about Paris’s pretensions as an Indo-Pacific power. 

>In the face of China’s expansionist ambitions, France has attempted to reassert its military might in the Indo-Pacific. Some 7,000 troops are deployed in the region. In 2020, for the first time in two decades, France sent a nuclear submarine to the Indo-Pacific as a means of signalling that it was willing and able to protect its interests there. 

>That strategy has been dealt a severe blow by the Aukus deal, which is widely viewed as Canberra giving Washington its vote of confidence over Paris as the ultimate anti-China power in the Indo-Pacific. Despite conciliatory noises from the three signatories, Paris’s anger has not subsided. France has accused the US and Australia of keeping it in the dark over negotiations for the new treaty and in the process marginalising a historic ally.
